1.quote: Be a free thinker and don't accept everything you hear as truth. Be critical and evaluate what you believe in.
1.author: aristotle

2.quote: Excellence is never an accident. It is always the result of high intention, sincere effort, and intelligent execution; it represents the wise choice of many alternatives - choice, not chance, determines your destiny.
2.author: aristotle

3.quote: To appreciate the beauty of a snowflake, it is necessary to stand out in the cold.
3.author: aristotle

4.quote: He who cannot be a good follower cannot be a good leader.
4.author: aristotle

5.quote: The weak are always anxious for justice and equality. The strong pay no heed to either.
5.author: aristotle

6.quote: Courage is the first virtue that makes all other virtues possible.
6.author: aristotle

7.quote: Laughter is a bodily exercise, precious to Health.
7.author: aristotle

8.quote: Greatness of spirit is accompanied by simplicity and sincerity.
8.author: aristotle

9.quote: Life is only meaningful when we are striving for a goal.
9.author: aristotle

10.quote: The most important relationship we can all have is the one you have with yourself, the most important journey you can take is one of self-discovery. To know yourself, you must spend time with yourself, you must not be afraid to be alone. Knowing yourself is the beginning of all wisdom.
10.author: aristotle

11.quote: Educating the mind without educating the heart is no education at all.
11.author: aristotle

12.quote: The more you know, the more you know you don't know.
12.author: aristotle

13.quote: 95% of everything you do is the result of habit.
13.author: aristotle

14.quote: A tragedy is that moment where the hero comes face to face with his true identity.
14.author: aristotle

15.quote: Men create gods after their own image, not only with regard to their form but with regard to their mode of life.
15.author: aristotle

16.quote: It is our choice of good or evil that determines our character, not our opinion about good or evil.
16.author: aristotle

17.quote: Our problem is not that we aim too high and miss, but that we aim too low and hit.
17.author: aristotle

18.quote: Criticism is something we can avoid easily by saying nothing, doing nothing, and being nothing.
18.author: aristotle

19.quote: At the intersection where your gifts, talents, and abilities meet a human need, therein you will discover your purpose.
19.author: aristotle

20.quote: A fool contributes nothing worth hearing and takes offense at everything.
20.author: aristotle

21.quote: Happiness is a quality of the soul...not a function of one's material circumstances.
21.author: aristotle

22.quote: The worst form of inequality is to try to make unequal things equal.
22.author: aristotle

23.quote: The high-minded man must care more for the truth than for what people think.
23.author: aristotle

24.quote: Whosoever is delighted in solitude is either a wild beast or a god.
24.author: aristotle

25.quote: True happiness comes from gaining insight and growing into your best possible self. Otherwise, all you're having is immediate gratification pleasure, which is fleeting and doesn't grow you as a person.
25.author: aristotle

26.quote: The intelligence consists not only in the knowledge but also in the skill to apply the knowledge into practice.
26.author: aristotle

27.quote: Doubt is the beginning of wisdom.
27.author: aristotle

28.quote: The most perfect political community is one in which the middle class is in control, and outnumbers both of the other classes.
28.author: aristotle

29.quote: Humility is a flower that does not grow in everyone's garden.
29.author: aristotle

30.quote: The best things are placed between extremes.
30.author: aristotle

31.quote: Character is determined by choice, not opinion.
31.author: aristotle

32.quote: Pleasure in the job puts perfection in the work.
32.author: aristotle

33.quote: The worst thing about slavery is that the slaves eventually get to like it.
33.author: aristotle

35.quote: Think as the wise men think, but talk like the simple people do.
35.author: aristotle

36.quote: We are what we repeatedly do... excellence, therefore, isn't just an act, but a habit and life isn't just a series of events, but an ongoing process of self-definition.
36.author: aristotle

37.quote: Life cannot be lived, and understood, simultaneously.
37.author: aristotle

38.quote: Excellence is an art won by training and habituation.
38.author: aristotle

39.quote: The roots of education are bitter, but the fruit is sweet.
39.author: aristotle

40.quote: Tyrants preserve themselves by sowing fear and mistrust among the citizens by means of spies, by distracting them with foreign wars, by eliminating men of spirit who might lead a revolution, by humbling the people, and making them incapable of decisive action.
40.author: aristotle

41.quote: He who has overcome his fears will truly be free.
41.author: aristotle

42.quote: The fool tells me his reason; the wise man persuades me with my own.
42.author: aristotle

43.quote: Only an armed people can be truly free. Only an unarmed people can ever be enslaved.
43.author: aristotle

44.quote: You will never do anything in this world without courage. It is the greatest quality of the mind next to honor.
44.author: aristotle

45.quote: Masculine republics give way to feminine democracies, and feminine democracies give way to tyranny.
45.author: aristotle

46.quote: If something's bound to happen, it will happen... Right time, right person, and for the best reason.
46.author: aristotle

47.quote: Youth is easily deceived because it is quick to hope.
47.author: aristotle

48.quote: A friend of everyone is a friend of no one.
48.author: aristotle

49.quote: What is the essence of life? To serve others and to do good.
49.author: aristotle

50.quote: Anybody can become angry - that is easy. But to be angry with the right person and to the right degree and at the right time and for the right purpose, and in the right way - that is not within everybody's power and is not easy.
50.author: aristotle

51.quote: It is the mark of an educated mind to be able to entertain a thought without accepting it.
51.author: aristotle

52.quote: Before you heal the body, you must first heal the mind.
52.author: aristotle

54.quote: Music directly represents the passions of the soul. If one listens to the wrong kind of music, he will become the wrong kind of person.
54.author: aristotle

55.quote: The high-minded man does not bear grudges, for it is not the mark of a great soul to remember injuries, but to forget them.
55.author: aristotle

56.quote: The proof that you know something is that you are able to teach it.
56.author: aristotle

57.quote: One may go wrong in many different ways, but right only in one, which is why it is easy to fail and difficult to succeed.
57.author: aristotle

58.quote: For both excessive and insufficient exercise, destroy one's strength, and both eating and drinking too much or too little destroy health, whereas the right quantity produces, increases and preserves it. So it is the same with temperance, courage and the other virtues. This much then, is clear: in all our conduct, it is the mean that is to be commended.
58.author: aristotle

59.quote: First, have a definite, clear practical ideal; a goal, an objective. Second, have the necessary means to achieve your ends; wisdom, money, materials, and methods. Third, adjust all your means to that end.
59.author: aristotle

60.quote: Those who are not angry at the things they should be angry at are thought to be fools, and so are those who are not angry in the right way, at the right time, or with the right persons.
60.author: aristotle

61.quote: When there is no middle class, and the poor greatly exceed in number, troubles arise, and the state soon comes to an end.
61.author: aristotle

62.quote: I count him braver who overcomes his desires than him who conquers his enemies; for the hardest victory is over self.
62.author: aristotle

63.quote: He who has never learned to obey cannot be a good commander.
63.author: aristotle

64.quote: Today, see if you can stretch your heart and expand your love so that it touches not only those to whom you can give it easily, but also to those who need it so much.
64.author: aristotle

65.quote: No great mind has ever existed without a touch of madness.
65.author: aristotle

66.quote: Knowing yourself is the beginning of all wisdom.
66.author: aristotle

67.quote: Whatever we learn to do, we learn by actually doing it; men come to be builders, for instance, by building, and harp players by playing the harp. In the same way, by doing just acts we come to be just; by doing self-controlled acts, we come to be self-controlled; and by doing brave acts, we become brave.
67.author: aristotle

68.quote: The greatest thing by far is to be a master of metaphor; it is the one thing that cannot be learned from others; and it is also a sign of genius, since a good metaphor implies an intuitive perception of the similarity of the dissimilar.
68.author: aristotle

69.quote: The society that loses its grip on the past is in danger, for it produces men who know nothing but the present, and who are not aware that life had been, and could be, different from what it is.
69.author: aristotle

70.quote: Courage is the mother of all virtues because without it, you cannot consistently perform the others.
70.author: aristotle

71.quote: Teenagers these days are out of control. They eat like pigs, they are disrespectful of adults, they interrupt and contradict their parents, and they terrorize their teachers.
71.author: aristotle

72.quote: Character is made by many acts; it may be lost by a single one.
72.author: aristotle

73.quote: The man who is perfect and wise will bear with dignity whatever fortune sends, and will always make the best of his circumstances.
73.author: aristotle

74.quote: Find the good. Seek unity. Ignore the divisions among us.
74.author: aristotle

75.quote: The greatest of all pleasures is the pleasure of learning.
75.author: aristotle

76.quote: The tyrant, who in order to hold his power, suppresses every superiority, does away with good men, forbids education and light, controls every movement of the citizens and, keeping them under a perpetual servitude, wants them to grow accustomed to baseness and cowardice, has his spies everywhere to listen to what is said in the meetings, and spreads dissension and calumny among the citizens and impoverishes them, is obliged to make war in order to keep his subjects occupied and impose on them permanent need of a chief.
76.author: aristotle

77.quote: Poverty is the parent of revolution and crime.
77.author: aristotle

78.quote: The hardest victory is the victory over self.
78.author: aristotle

79.quote: Republics decline into democracies and democracies degenerate into despotism.
79.author: aristotle

81.quote: You are what you repeatedly do.
81.author: aristotle

82.quote: Your happiness depends on you alone.
82.author: aristotle

83.quote: Patience is bitter, but it is fruit is sweet.
83.author: aristotle

84.quote: Wise people have an inward sense of what is beautiful, and the highest wisdom is to trust this intuition and be guided by it.
84.author: aristotle

85.quote: Knowledge of the fact differs from knowledge of the reason for the fact.
85.author: aristotle

86.quote: The energy of the mind is the essence of life.
86.author: aristotle

87.quote: The aim of the wise is not to secure pleasure, but to avoid pain.
87.author: aristotle

88.quote: Our feelings towards our friends reflect our feelings towards ourselves.
88.author: aristotle

89.quote: They - young people have exalted notions, because they have not been humbled by life or learned its necessary limitations; moreover, their hopeful disposition makes them think themselves equal to great things - and that means having exalted notions. They would always rather do noble deeds than useful ones: Their lives are regulated more by moral feeling than by reasoning - all their mistakes are in the direction of doing things excessively and vehemently. They overdo everything - they love too much, hate too much, and the same with everything else.
89.author: aristotle

91.quote: The quality of life is determined by its activities.
91.author: aristotle

92.quote: What you have to learn to do, you learn by doing.
92.author: aristotle

93.quote: Man is a goal-seeking animal. His life only has meaning if he is reaching out and striving for his goals.
93.author: aristotle

94.quote: All persons ought to endeavor to follow what is right, and not what is established.
94.author: aristotle

95.quote: A goal gets us motivated, while a good habit keeps us stay motivated.
95.author: aristotle

96.quote: The best way to avoid envy is to deserve the success you get.
96.author: aristotle

97.quote: You can never learn anything that you did not already know.
97.author: aristotle

98.quote: There is nothing unequal as the equal treatment of unequals.
98.author: aristotle

99.quote: Virtue means doing the right thing, in relation to the right person, at the right time, to the right extent, in the right manner, and for the right purpose. Thus, to give money away is quite a simple task, but for the act to be virtuous, the donor must give to the right person, for the right purpose, in the right amount, in the right manner, and at the right time.
99.author: aristotle

100.quote: It is a part of probability that many improbable things will happen.
100.author: aristotle

101.quote: Those that know, do. Those that understand, teach.
101.author: aristotle

102.quote: We are the sum of our actions, and therefore our habits make all the difference.
102.author: aristotle

103.quote: It is impossible, or not easy, to alter by argument what has long been absorbed by habit.
103.author: aristotle

104.quote: Let us first understand the facts, and then we may seek the cause.
104.author: aristotle

105.quote: We laugh at that which we cannot bear to face.
105.author: aristotle

106.quote: Peace is more difficult than war.
106.author: aristotle

107.quote: You are what you do repeatedly.
107.author: aristotle

108.quote: Anyone who has no need of anybody but himself is either a beast or a God.
108.author: aristotle

109.quote: The greatest crimes are caused by surfeit, not by want.
109.author: aristotle

110.quote: To Unlearn is as hard as to Learn.
110.author: aristotle

111.quote: Every man should be responsible to others, nor should anyone be allowed to do just as he pleases; for where absolute freedom is allowed, there is nothing to restrain the evil which is inherent in every man.
111.author: aristotle

112.quote: The only way to achieve true success is to express yourself completely in service to society.
112.author: aristotle

113.quote: Friends hold a mirror up to each other; through that mirror they can see each other in ways that would not otherwise be accessible to them, and it is this mirroring that helps them improve themselves as persons.
113.author: aristotle

114.quote: A proper wife should be as obedient as a slave... The female is a female by virtue of a certain lack of qualities - a natural defectiveness.
114.author: aristotle

115.quote: Love is composed of a single soul inhabiting two bodies.
115.author: aristotle

116.quote: Love well, be loved and do something of value.
116.author: aristotle

117.quote: Happiness is a state of activity.
117.author: aristotle

118.quote: Man is by nature a social animal; an individual who is unsocial naturally and not accidentally is either beneath our notice or more than human. Society is something that precedes the individual. Anyone who either cannot lead the common life or is so self-sufficient as not to need to, and therefore does not partake of society, is either a beast or a god.
118.author: aristotle

119.quote: Fine friendship requires duration rather than fitful intensity.
119.author: aristotle

120.quote: The physician himself, if sick, actually calls in another physician, knowing that he cannot reason correctly if required to judge his own condition while suffering.
120.author: aristotle

121.quote: Money is a guarantee that we can have what we want in the future.
121.author: aristotle

122.quote: Those who cannot bravely face danger are the slaves of their attackers.
122.author: aristotle

123.quote: The beauty of the soul shines out when a man bears with composure one heavy mischance after another, not because he feels them, but because he is a man of high and heroic temper.
123.author: aristotle

125.quote: Health is a matter of choice, not a mystery of chance.
125.author: aristotle

126.quote: To love someone is to identify with them.
126.author: aristotle

127.quote: He overcomes a stout enemy who overcomes his own anger.
127.author: aristotle

128.quote: All men seek one goal: success or happiness.
128.author: aristotle

129.quote: Democracy is when the indigent, and not the men of property, are the rulers.
129.author: aristotle

130.quote: It is well to be up before daybreak, for such habits contribute to health, wealth, and wisdom.
130.author: aristotle

132.quote: Speech is the representation of the mind, and writing is the representation of speech.
132.author: aristotle

133.quote: Plato is my friend, but truth is a better friend.
133.author: aristotle

134.quote: We should aim rather at leveling down our desires than leveling up our means.
134.author: aristotle

135.quote: At his best, man is the noblest of all animals; separated from law and justice, he is the worst.
135.author: aristotle

136.quote: It would be wrong to put friendship before the truth.
136.author: aristotle

137.quote: The difference between a learned man and an ignorant one is the same as that between a living man and a corpse.
137.author: aristotle

138.quote: A promise made must be a promise kept.
138.author: aristotle

139.quote: Of the tyrant, spies and informers are the principal instruments. War is his favorite occupation, for the sake of engrossing the attention of the people, and making himself necessary to them as their leader.
139.author: aristotle

140.quote: Nature creates nothing without a purpose.
140.author: aristotle

141.quote: There are no experienced young people. Time makes experience.
141.author: aristotle

142.quote: Where your talents and the needs of the world cross; there lies your vocation.
142.author: aristotle

143.quote: The man who is content to live alone is either a beast or a god.
143.author: aristotle

144.quote: The soul suffers when the body is diseased or traumatized, while the body suffers when the soul is ailing.
144.author: aristotle

145.quote: The Fate of empires depends on the education of youth.
145.author: aristotle

146.quote: Obstinate people can be divided into the opinionated, the ignorant, and the boorish.
146.author: aristotle

147.quote: All paid jobs absorb and degrade the mind.
147.author: aristotle

148.quote: The ideal man is his own best friend and takes delight in privacy.
148.author: aristotle

149.quote: Both oligarch and tyrant mistrust the people, and therefore deprive them of their arms.
149.author: aristotle

150.quote: A gentleman is not disturbed by anything.
150.author: aristotle

151.quote: He who cannot see the truth for himself, nor, hearing it from others, stores it away in his mind that man is utterly worthless.
151.author: aristotle

152.quote: It is not sufficient to know what one ought to say, but one must also know how to say it.
152.author: aristotle

153.quote: Where your talents and the needs of the world cross, therein lies your vocation. These two, your talents and the needs of the world, are the great wake-up calls to your true vocation in life... to ignore this, is in some sense, is to lose your soul.
153.author: aristotle

154.quote: The best way to teach morality is to make it a habit with children.
154.author: aristotle

156.quote: It is better for a city to be governed by a good man than by good laws.
156.author: aristotle

157.quote: Men become richer not only by increasing their existing wealth but also by decreasing their expenditure.
157.author: aristotle

158.quote: All friendly feelings toward others come from the friendly feelings a person has for himself.
158.author: aristotle

159.quote: Of all the varieties of virtues, liberalism is the most beloved.
159.author: aristotle

160.quote: It belongs to small-mindedness to be unable to bear either honor or dishonor, either good fortune or bad, but to be filled with conceit when honored and puffed up by trifling good fortune, and to be unable to bear even the smallest dishonor and to deem any chance failure a great misfortune, and to be distressed and annoyed at everything. Moreover, the small-minded man is the sort of person to call all slights an insult and dishonor, even those that are due to ignorance or forgetfulness. Small-mindedness is accompanied by pettiness, querulousness, pessimism and self-abasement.
160.author: aristotle

161.quote: The end of labor is to gain leisure.
161.author: aristotle

162.quote: The self-indulgent man craves for all pleasant things... and is led by his appetite to choose these at the cost of everything else.
162.author: aristotle

163.quote: Friendship is a thing most necessary to life, since without friends no one would choose to live, though possessed of all other advantages.
163.author: aristotle

164.quote: A democracy exists whenever those who are free and are not well-off, being in the majority, are in sovereign control of government, an oligarchy when control lies with the rich and better-born, these being few.
164.author: aristotle

165.quote: There is honor in being a dog.
165.author: aristotle

166.quote: If you see a man approaching with the obvious intent of doing you good, run for your life.
166.author: aristotle

167.quote: Consider pleasures as they depart, not as they come.
167.author: aristotle

168.quote: God and nature create nothing that does not fulfill a purpose.
168.author: aristotle

169.quote: Art is a higher type of knowledge than experience.
169.author: aristotle

171.quote: The character which results from wealth is that of a prosperous fool.
171.author: aristotle

172.quote: Misfortune shows those who are not really friends.
172.author: aristotle

173.quote: It is of the nature of desire not to be satisfied, and most men live only for the gratification of it.
173.author: aristotle

174.quote: Suffering becomes beautiful when anyone bears great calamities with cheerfulness, not through insensibility but through greatness of mind.
174.author: aristotle

175.quote: Authority is no source of Truth.
175.author: aristotle

176.quote: People do not naturally become morally excellent or practically wise. They become so, if at all, only as the result of lifelong personal and community effort.
176.author: aristotle

177.quote: Reason is a light that God has kindled in the soul.
177.author: aristotle

178.quote: What we expect, that we find.
178.author: aristotle

179.quote: We are better able to study our neighbours than ourselves and their actions than our own.
179.author: aristotle

180.quote: We work to earn our leisure.
180.author: aristotle

181.quote: Friendship is a single soul dwelling in two bodies.
181.author: aristotle

182.quote: Female cats are very Lascivious, and make advances to the male.
182.author: aristotle

184.quote: Dignity does not consist in possessing honors, but in deserving them.
184.author: aristotle

185.quote: He who sees things grow from the beginning will have the best view of them.
185.author: aristotle

186.quote: Time crumbles things; everything grows old under the power of Time and is forgotten through the lapse of Time.
186.author: aristotle

187.quote: If men are given food, but no chastisement nor any work, they become insolent.
187.author: aristotle

188.quote: Friends are much better tried in bad fortune than in good.
188.author: aristotle

189.quote: Happiness is the reward of virtue.
189.author: aristotle

190.quote: It is the characteristic of the magnanimous man to ask no favor but to be ready to do kindness to others.
190.author: aristotle

191.quote: The senses are gateways to the intelligence. There is nothing in the intelligence that did not first pass through the senses.
191.author: aristotle

192.quote: We become just by the practice of just actions, self-controlled by exercising self-control, and courageous by performing acts of courage.
192.author: aristotle

193.quote: It is more difficult to organize a peace than to win a war; but the fruits of victory will be lost if the peace is not organized.
193.author: aristotle

194.quote: What it lies in our power to do, it lies in our power not to do.
194.author: aristotle

195.quote: If you understand anything, observe its beginning and its development.
195.author: aristotle

196.quote: If things do not turn out as we wish, we should wish for them as they turn out.
196.author: aristotle

197.quote: Man is by nature a political animal.
197.author: aristotle

198.quote: The ultimate end...is not knowledge, but action. To be half right on time may be more important than to obtain the whole truth too late.
198.author: aristotle

199.quote: The only stable state is the one in which all men are equal before the law.
199.author: aristotle

200.quote: Saying the words that come from knowledge is no sign of having it.
200.author: aristotle

202.quote: The whole is more than the sum of its parts.
202.author: aristotle

203.quote: Worthless persons appointed to have supreme control of weighty affairs do a lot of damage.
203.author: aristotle

204.quote: The habits we form from childhood make no small difference, but rather they make all the difference.
204.author: aristotle

205.quote: Our characters are the result of our conduct.
205.author: aristotle

206.quote: The soul never thinks without a picture.
206.author: aristotle

208.quote: There's many a slip between the cup and the lip.
208.author: aristotle

209.quote: The greatest thing by far is to have a command of metaphor. This alone cannot be imparted by another; it is the mark of genius, for to make good metaphors implies an eye for resemblances.
209.author: aristotle

210.quote: Men are marked from the moment of birth to rule or be ruled.
210.author: aristotle

211.quote: My best friend is the man who in wishing me well wishes it for my sake.
211.author: aristotle

212.quote: To say of what is that it is not, or of what is not that it is, is false, while to say of what is that it is, and of what is not that it is not, is true.
212.author: aristotle

213.quote: We should behave to our friends as we would wish our friends to behave to us.
213.author: aristotle

214.quote: Happiness does not consist in pastimes and amusements but in virtuous activities.
214.author: aristotle

215.quote: Truth is a remarkable thing. We cannot miss knowing some of it. But we cannot know it entirely.
215.author: aristotle

216.quote: Jealousy is both reasonable and belongs to reasonable men, while envy is base and belongs to the base, for the one makes himself get good things by jealousy, while the other does not allow his neighbor to have them through envy.
216.author: aristotle

217.quote: Fear is pain arising from the anticipation of evil.
217.author: aristotle

219.quote: Excellence, therefore, is not an act, but a habit.
219.author: aristotle

220.quote: He who hath many friends hath none.
220.author: aristotle

221.quote: No state will be well administered unless the middle class holds sway.
221.author: aristotle

222.quote: By myth, I mean the arrangement of the incidents.
222.author: aristotle

223.quote: The honors and rewards fall to those who show their good qualities in action.
223.author: aristotle

224.quote: Happiness is the meaning and the purpose of life, the whole aim and end of human existence.
224.author: aristotle

225.quote: Excellence, then, is a state concerned with choice, lying in a mean, relative to us, this being determined by reason and in the way in which the man of practical wisdom would determine it.
225.author: aristotle

226.quote: No one loves the man whom he fears.
226.author: aristotle

227.quote: Now the greatest external good we should assume to be the thing which we offer as a tribute to the gods, and which is most coveted by men of high station, and is the prize awarded for the noblest deeds; and such a thing is honor, for honor is clearly the greatest of external goods.
227.author: aristotle

228.quote: For what one has to learn to do, we learn by doing.
228.author: aristotle

229.quote: Happiness is the settling of the soul into its most appropriate spot.
229.author: aristotle

230.quote: It is no easy task to be good.
230.author: aristotle

231.quote: The Nature of man is not what he was born as, but what he is born for.
231.author: aristotle

232.quote: Worms are the intestines of the earth.
232.author: aristotle

233.quote: True happiness flows from the possession of wisdom and virtue and not from the possession of external goods.
233.author: aristotle

234.quote: The hand is the tool of tools.
234.author: aristotle

235.quote: Friends enhance our ability to think and act.
235.author: aristotle

236.quote: We are what we frequently do.
236.author: aristotle

237.quote: A tyrant must put on the appearance of uncommon devotion to religion. Subjects are less apprehensive of illegal treatment from a ruler whom they consider god-fearing and pious. On the other hand, they do less easily move against him, believing that he has the gods on his side.
237.author: aristotle

238.quote: Beauty is the gift of God.
238.author: aristotle

239.quote: Bad people...are in conflict with themselves; they desire one thing and will another, like the incontinent who choose harmful pleasures instead of what they themselves believe to be good.
239.author: aristotle

240.quote: Good moral character is not something that we can achieve on our own. We need a culture that supports the conditions under which self-love and friendship flourish.
240.author: aristotle

241.quote: To write well, express yourself like the common people, but think like a wise man.
241.author: aristotle

242.quote: Teachers, who educate children, deserve more honor than parents, who merely gave them birth; for the latter provided mere life, while the former ensure a good life.
242.author: aristotle

243.quote: Money was intended to be used in exchange, but not to increase at interest. And this term interest, which means the birth of money from money, is applied to the breeding of money because the offspring resembles the parent. Wherefore of all modes of getting wealth, this is the most unnatural.
243.author: aristotle

244.quote: The complete man must work, study and wrestle.
244.author: aristotle

245.quote: The wise man does not expose himself needlessly to danger, since there are few things for which he cares sufficiently; but he is willing, in great crises, to give even his life - knowing that under certain conditions it is not worthwhile to live.
245.author: aristotle

247.quote: Even that some people try deceived me many times ... I will not fail to believe that somewhere, someone deserves my trust.
247.author: aristotle

248.quote: A person's life persuades better than his word.
248.author: aristotle

249.quote: All Earthquakes and Disasters are warnings; there s too much corruption in the world.
249.author: aristotle

250.quote: For man, when perfected, is the best of animals, but, when separated from law and justice, he is the worst of all; since armed injustice is the more dangerous, and he is equipped at birth with the arms of intelligence and with moral qualities which he may use for the worst ends. Wherefore, if he has no virtue, he is the most unholy and the most savage of animals, and the most full of lust and gluttony. But justice is the bond of men in states, and the administration of justice, which is the determination of what is just, is the principle of order in political society.
250.author: aristotle

251.quote: A common danger unites even the bitterest enemies.
251.author: aristotle

252.quote: Being a father is the most rewarding thing a man whose career has plateaued can do.
252.author: aristotle

253.quote: It is simplicity that makes the uneducated more effective than the educated when addressing popular audiences.
253.author: aristotle

254.quote: Maybe crying is a means of cleaning yourself out emotionally. Or maybe it's your last resort; the only way to express yourself when words fail, the same as when you were a baby and had no words.
254.author: aristotle

255.quote: Happiness, whether consisting in pleasure or virtue, or both, is more often found with those who are highly cultivated in their minds and in their character, and have only a moderate share of external goods, than among those who possess external goods to a useless extent but are deficient in higher qualities.
255.author: aristotle

256.quote: Nature does nothing in vain. Therefore, it is imperative for persons to act in accordance with their nature and develop their latent talents, in order to be content and complete.
256.author: aristotle

257.quote: The ideal man takes joy in doing favors for others.
257.author: aristotle

258.quote: Yes, the truth is that men's ambition and their desire to make money are among the most frequent causes of deliberate acts of injustice.
258.author: aristotle

259.quote: Try is a noisy way of doing nothing.
259.author: aristotle

260.quote: Life in the true sense is perceiving or thinking.
260.author: aristotle

261.quote: He is his own best friend and takes delight in privacy, whereas the man of no virtue or ability is his own worst enemy and is afraid of solitude.
261.author: aristotle

262.quote: Consider pleasures as they depart, not as they come.
262.author: aristotle

263.quote: You should never think without an image.
263.author: aristotle

264.quote: The actuality of thought is life.
264.author: aristotle

265.quote: Gentleness is the ability to bear reproaches and slights with moderation, and not to embark on revenge quickly, and not to be easily provoked to anger, but be free from bitterness and contentiousness, having tranquility and stability in the spirit.
265.author: aristotle

266.quote: The greatest victory is over self.
266.author: aristotle

268.quote: Intuition is the source of scientific knowledge.
268.author: aristotle

270.quote: Friends are an aid to the young, to guard them from error; to the elderly, to attend to their wants and to supplement their failing power of action; to those in the prime of life, to assist them to noble deeds.
270.author: aristotle

271.quote: When you feel yourself lacking something, send your thoughts towards your Intimate and search for the Divinity that lives within you.
271.author: aristotle

272.quote: When...we, as individuals, obey laws that direct us to behave for the welfare of the community as a whole, we are indirectly helping to promote the pursuit of happiness by our fellow human beings.
272.author: aristotle

273.quote: Education is an ornament in prosperity and a refuge in adversity.
273.author: aristotle

274.quote: Business or toil is merely utilitarian. It is necessary but does not enrich or ennoble a human life.
274.author: aristotle

275.quote: Goodness is to do good to the deserving and love the good and hate the wicked, and not to be eager to inflict punishment or take vengeance, but to be gracious and kindly and forgiving.
275.author: aristotle

276.quote: For though we love both the truth and our friends, piety requires us to honor the truth first.
276.author: aristotle

277.quote: The family is the association established by nature for the supply of men's everyday wants.
277.author: aristotle

278.quote: Self-sufficiency is both a good and an absolute good.
278.author: aristotle

279.quote: Liars when they speak the truth are not believed.
279.author: aristotle

280.quote: Happiness involves engagement in activities that promote one's highest potential.
280.author: aristotle

281.quote: The Life of the intellect is the best and pleasantest for man, because the intellect more than anything else is the man. Thus, it will be the happiest life as well.
281.author: aristotle

282.quote: Music directly imitates the passions or states of the soul...when one listens to music that imitates a certain passion, he becomes imbued with the same passion; and if over a long time he habitually listens to music that rouses ignoble passions, his whole character will be shaped to an ignoble form.
282.author: aristotle

283.quote: We give up leisure in order that we may have leisure, just as we go to war in order that we may have peace.
283.author: aristotle

284.quote: Meanness is incurable; it cannot be cured by old age or by anything else.
284.author: aristotle

285.quote: There is no genius who hasn't a touch of insanity.
285.author: aristotle

286.quote: We must be neither cowardly nor rash but courageous.
286.author: aristotle

287.quote: Memory is the scribe of the soul.
287.author: aristotle

288.quote: Each human being is bred with a unique set of potentials that yearn to be fulfilled as surely as the acorn yearns to become the oak within it.
288.author: aristotle

289.quote: The true nature of anything is what it becomes at its highest.
289.author: aristotle

290.quote: Why do men seek honour? Surely, in order to confirm the favorable opinion, they have formed of themselves.
290.author: aristotle

291.quote: Salt water when it turns into vapour becomes sweet, and the vapour does not form salt water when it condenses again. This I know by experiment. The same thing is true in every case of the kind: wine and all fluids that evaporate and condense back into a liquid state become water. They all are water modified by a certain admixture, the nature of which determines their flavor.
291.author: aristotle

292.quote: To give away money is an easy matter and in any man's power. But to decide to whom to give it and how large and when, and for what purpose and how, is neither in every man's power nor an easy matter.
292.author: aristotle

293.quote: Democracy is the form of government in which the free, are rulers.
293.author: aristotle

294.quote: Mothers are fonder than fathers of their children because they are more certain they are their own.
294.author: aristotle

295.quote: Neither should we forget the mean, which at the present day is lost sight of in perverted forms of government; for many practices which appear to be democratic are the ruin of democracies. Those who think that all virtue is to be found in their own party principles push matters to extremes; they do not consider that disproportion destroys a state.
295.author: aristotle

296.quote: A flatterer is a friend who is your inferior, or pretends to be so.
296.author: aristotle

298.quote: The aim of art is to represent not the outward appearance of things, but their inward significance.
298.author: aristotle

299.quote: A man's happiness consists in the free exercise of his highest faculties.
299.author: aristotle

300.quote: For, what is the best choice for each individual is the highest it is possible for him to achieve.
300.author: aristotle

301.quote: Good has two meanings: it means that which is good absolutely and that which is good for somebody.
301.author: aristotle

302.quote: Excellence is an art won by training and habituation. We do not act rightly because we have virtue or excellence, but we rather have those because we have acted rightly. We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence, then, is not an act but a habit.
302.author: aristotle

303.quote: Law is a mind without reason.
303.author: aristotle

304.quote: Those who act receive the prizes.
304.author: aristotle

305.quote: Suppose, then, that all men were sick or deranged, save one or two of them who were healthy and of right mind. It would then be the latter two who would be thought to be sick and deranged, and the former not.
305.author: aristotle

306.quote: That which is impossible and probable is better than that which is possible and improbable.
306.author: aristotle

307.quote: A man becomes a friend whenever being loved he loves in return.
307.author: aristotle

308.quote: We are what we continually do.
308.author: aristotle

309.quote: Character is that which reveals moral purpose, exposing the class of things a man chooses and avoids.
309.author: aristotle

310.quote: Education and morals make the good man, the good statesman, the good ruler.
310.author: aristotle

311.quote: The young are heated by Nature as drunken men by wine.
311.author: aristotle

312.quote: Happiness is a certain activity of soul in conformity with perfect goodness.
312.author: aristotle

313.quote: Revolutions are effected in two ways, by force and by fraud.
313.author: aristotle

315.quote: Education and morals will be found almost the whole that goes to make a good man.
315.author: aristotle

316.quote: Experience has shown that it is difficult, if not impossible, for a populous state to be run by good laws.
316.author: aristotle

317.quote: Wonder implies the desire to learn.
317.author: aristotle

318.quote: Bad men are full of repentance.
318.author: aristotle

319.quote: Every man should be responsible to others, nor should anyone be allowed to do just as he pleases; for where absolute freedom is allowed, there is nothing to restrain the evil which is inherent in every man. But the principle of responsibility secures that which is the greatest good in states; the right persons rule and are prevented from doing wrong, and the people have their due. It is evident that this is the best kind of democracy, and why? because the people are drawn from a certain class.
319.author: aristotle

320.quote: It was through the feeling of wonder that men now and at first began to philosophize.
320.author: aristotle

321.quote: When you ask a dumb question, you get a smart answer.
321.author: aristotle

322.quote: It is not once nor twice but times without number that the same ideas make their appearance in the world.
322.author: aristotle

323.quote: The angry man wishes the object of his anger to suffer in return; hatred wishes its object not to exist.
323.author: aristotle

324.quote: The duty of rhetoric is to deal with such matters as we deliberate upon without arts or systems to guide us, in the hearing of persons who cannot take in at a glance a complicated argument or follow a long chain of reasoning.
324.author: aristotle

325.quote: Men are divided between those who are as thrifty as if they would live forever, and those who are as extravagant as if they were going to die the next day.
325.author: aristotle

326.quote: There are branches of learning and education that we must study merely with a view to leisure spent in intellectual activity, and these are to be valued for their own sake; whereas those kinds of knowledge which are useful in business are to be deemed necessary, and exist for the sake of other things.
326.author: aristotle

327.quote: The soul becomes prudent by sitting and being quiet.
327.author: aristotle

328.quote: Bashfulness is an ornament to youth, but a reproach to old age.
328.author: aristotle

329.quote: Nothing is what rocks dream about.
329.author: aristotle

330.quote: The aim of education is to make the pupil like and dislike what he ought... The little human animal will not at first have the right responses. It must be trained to feel pleasure, liking, disgust, and hatred at those things which really are pleasant, likable, disgusting, and hateful.
330.author: aristotle

331.quote: The least initial deviation from the truth is multiplied later a thousandfold.
331.author: aristotle

332.quote: There are two distinctive peculiarities by reference to which we characterize the soul (1) local movement and (2) thinking, discriminating, and perceiving. Thinking both speculative and practical is regarded as akin to a form of perceiving; for in the one as well as the other, the soul discriminates and is cognizant of something that is.
332.author: aristotle

333.quote: The antidote for fifty enemies is one friend.
333.author: aristotle

334.quote: Happiness is the utilization of one's talents along lines of excellence.
334.author: aristotle

335.quote: It is Homer who has chiefly taught other poets the art of telling lies skillfully.
335.author: aristotle

336.quote: In educating the young, we steer them by the rudders of pleasure and pain.
336.author: aristotle

337.quote: Plot is character revealed by action.
337.author: aristotle

338.quote: Humor is the only test of gravity, and gravity of humor; for a subject which will not bear raillery is suspicious, and a jest which will not bear serious examination is false wit.
338.author: aristotle

339.quote: For we do not think that we know a thing until we are acquainted with its primary conditions or first principles, and have carried our analysis as far as its simplest elements.
339.author: aristotle

340.quote: Virtue makes us aim at the right end, and practical wisdom makes us take the right means.
340.author: aristotle

341.quote: To run away from trouble is a form of cowardice, and while it is true that the suicide braves death, he does it not for some noble object but to escape some ill.
341.author: aristotle

342.quote: Even the best of men in authority are liable to be corrupted by passion. We may conclude then that the law is reason without passion, and it is therefore preferable to any individual.
342.author: aristotle

343.quote: Personal beauty requires that one should be tall; little people may have charm and elegance, but beauty-no.
343.author: aristotle

344.quote: The life of money-making is one undertaken under compulsion, and wealth is evidently not the good we are seeking; for it is merely useful and for the sake of something else.
344.author: aristotle

345.quote: Thinking is different from perceiving and is held to be in part imagination, in part judgment.
345.author: aristotle

346.quote: The ultimate value of life depends upon awareness and the power of contemplation rather than upon mere survival.
346.author: aristotle

348.quote: Women should marry when they are about eighteen years of age, and men at seven and thirty; then they are in the prime of life, and the decline in the powers of both will coincide.
348.author: aristotle

349.quote: It is unbecoming for young men to utter maxims.
349.author: aristotle

350.quote: The activity of happiness must occupy an entire lifetime; for one swallow does not a summer make.
350.author: aristotle

352.quote: Democracy appears to be safer and less liable to revolution than oligarchy. For in oligarchies there is the double danger of the oligarchs falling out among themselves and also with the people; but in democracies there is only the danger of a quarrel with the oligarchs. No dissension worth mentioning arises among the people themselves. And we may further remark that a government which is composed of the middle class more nearly approximates to democracy than to oligarchy, and is the safest of the imperfect forms of government.
352.author: aristotle

353.quote: One who faces and who fears the right things and from the right motive, in the right way and at the right time, possesses a character worthy of our trust and admiration.
353.author: aristotle

354.quote: Civil confusions often spring from trifles but decide great issues.
354.author: aristotle

355.quote: The brave man, if he is compared with the coward, seems foolhardy; and, if with the foolhardy man, seems a coward.
355.author: aristotle

356.quote: How much a dispute could have been deflated into a single paragraph if the disputants had dared to define their terms.
356.author: aristotle

357.quote: A true disciple shows his appreciation by reaching further than his teacher.
357.author: aristotle

358.quote: Youth loves honor and victory more than money.
358.author: aristotle

359.quote: Education is the best provision for old age.
359.author: aristotle

360.quote: All men by nature desire knowledge.
360.author: aristotle

361.quote: Comedy aims at representing men as worse, Tragedy as better than in actual life.
361.author: aristotle

362.quote: The young are permanently in a state resembling intoxication.
362.author: aristotle

363.quote: All human actions have one or more of these seven causes: chance, nature, compulsions, habit, reason, passion, desire.
363.author: aristotle

364.quote: Sophocles said he drew men as they ought to be, and Euripides as they were.
364.author: aristotle

365.quote: Of the modes of persuasion furnished by the spoken word, there are three kinds. The first kind depends on the personal character of the speaker; the second on putting the audience into a certain frame of mind; the third on the proof, provided by the words of the speech itself.
365.author: aristotle

366.quote: A very populous city can rarely, if ever, be well governed.
366.author: aristotle

367.quote: The Eyes are the organs of temptation, and the Ears are the organs of instruction.
367.author: aristotle

368.quote: Accordingly, the poet should prefer probable impossibilities to improbable possibilities. The tragic plot must not be composed of irrational parts.
368.author: aristotle

369.quote: To be angry is easy. But to be angry with the right man at the right time and in the right manner, that is not easy.
369.author: aristotle

370.quote: Definition of tragedy: A hero destroyed by the excess of his virtues.
370.author: aristotle

371.quote: Every rascal is not a thief, but every thief is a rascal.
371.author: aristotle

372.quote: The law is reason unaffected by desire.
372.author: aristotle

373.quote: Happiness comes from the perfect practice of virtue.
373.author: aristotle

374.quote: Every wicked man is in ignorance as to what he ought to do, and from what to abstain, and it is because of error such as this that men become unjust and, in a word, wicked.
374.author: aristotle

375.quote: The greatest virtues are those which are most useful to other persons.
375.author: aristotle

376.quote: Between husband and wife friendship seems to exist by nature, for man is naturally disposed to pairing.
376.author: aristotle

377.quote: The pleasures arising from thinking and learning will make us think and learn all the more.
377.author: aristotle
